results.title: Hospital heroes
results.creator_credit: Ben Moller and Royal Children's Hospital and District Health Service Education Centre
results.brief_description: Going to hospital is often a frightening experience, and in the case of children - a traumatic one too. ‘Hospital heroes’ attempts to demystify this process as it follows three brave children who are going to hospital. Brooke is going into hospital to have a grommet put in her ear; Nicholas takes a trip in an ambulance after suffering an asthma attack; and Anthony has fallen off a bike and injured his head and leg and is carried away in a helicopter. The children are visited by “Agro” and a companion. A resource workbook (prepared by Christine Black) accompanies the video and provides guidance on curriculum ideas related to language, art, science, maths and social studies. Suitable for all primary levels as well as lower secondary level students in relation to mathematics.

results.title: Hospital [NTSC]
results.brief_description: Since the 1960s Frederick Wiseman has been at the forefront of the direct cinema documentary movement. Interrogating the public and social institutions of the United States he has built up an acclaimed oeuvre which has greatly influenced filmmakers around the world. In “Hospital” he worked with the doctors, staff and patients of New York City’s Metropolitan Hospital Centre. Wiseman’s commitment to the aesthetics of cinema-verite means that there is no narration or exegesis in his film practice. Instead, the camera becomes an observer of the pressures and crisis of a public hospital in the USA. What emerges is a portrait of a public institution stretched to the limits and a damning condemnation of poverty in America. “Hospital” allows us to observe all aspects of hospital life: well-meaning but seriously over-worked doctors and psychologists; nurses and attendants; cleaners and ambulance workers. And finally there are the patients themselves. Whether their illnesses are due to drugs or alcohol, to old age and over-work, or to violence and accident, what we get to witness is the pressure of survival for people who live at the bottom of the American social order.

results.title: Hospice
results.brief_description: This film is about a new concept in caring for the terminally ill. Staff members explain how they help their patients on a day-to-day basis, trying to make life for the patient as easy as possible, free of physical and emotional pain, and with constant care attention given in a home-like atmosphere.

results.title: Hoppy: a portrait of Elizabeth Hopkins
results.creator_credit: Colin Browne, Don Hopkins, John Taylor and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Although a latecomer to the professional art scene, Elisabeth Hopkins has achieved success. In this film, the eighty-eight-year-old Canadian artist is seen, and heard, as she talks and paints her way through an interview. Fiercely independent, she lives alone and enjoys it. Scenes from her paintings, wittily underscored by a creative soundtrack, mix easily with scenes of her life on Galiano Island off the southern coast of British Columbia, and at the Bau-Xi Gallery in Toronto, where her paintings are eagerly snapped up. Elisabeth Hopkins has not allowed age to diminish her pleasure in life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Browne, Don Hopkins, John Taylor and ONF | NFB

results.title: Hoppin' mad [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: David McKay and David McKay Design
results.brief_description: Cold Chisel’s “Cheap wine” sing along by two travelling German tourists is rudely interrupted when their car hits a kangaroo. Not wanting to waste a photo opportunity with one of Australia’s most famous native animals, Rainer and Dirk take time out to pose with “Skippy”, with surprising results. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: Hopi Indians: arts and crafts
results.brief_description: Looks at the arts and crafts of the Hopi Indians focusing on weaving, silversmithing, basket making and pottery. Records the skill and patience required in these rapidly disappearing arts.

results.title: Hope Street (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Ivan Hexter and East West Films
results.brief_description: Homelessness is a major dilemma for many young Australians. Through the experiences of several young characters living in a refuge, caravan park and squat, Hope Street explores the reasons for their homelessness, the impact it has on their lives and the ways in which these young people endeavour to resolve their predicaments.

results.title: Hong Kong: far eastern outpost of the empire
results.brief_description: Gives a brief history of the British colony, followed by scenes of the harbour with its houseboats and junks, the farmlands with traditional farming methods, shops and houses, and the streets full of people.

results.title: Honey harvest
results.creator_credit: Norman A. Uren, Department of Agriculture Western Australia and Western Australian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows the gathering of honey from wildflowers. It is a seasonal activity and beekeepers move the hives to follow the honey flow throughout the state. The film depicts the extraction of honey, packing and bulk handling. Honey is loaded at Fremantle and shipped overseas. Commercial uses of honey are also indicated.

results.title: Honey bees and pollination
results.creator_credit: J.V. Durden, Larry Gosnell, David Bairstow and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A color film showing the relationship between the activity of bees and the fertility of field and orchard crops. Much of the film is in close-up so that the process of cross-pollination of flowers by bees can be clearly observed. The life of the hive is similarly illustrated, including the peculiar dance by which a successful bee tells the others where its source of honey is located. The film warns that indiscriminate use of chemical sprays may destroy bees, with consequent loss of fertility in crops.
